layman:
**DIAGNOSIS ON ADMISSION:**  
Blood loss in the digestive tract.

**DIAGNOSES ON DISCHARGE**  
1. Blood loss in the digestive tract – the exact source isn’t clear, but it may be from internal hemorrhoids.  
2. Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (hardening of the arteries).  
3. Hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid).

**PROCEDURE**  
Colonoscopy (a camera exam of the colon).

**FINDINGS**  
The colon prep was not great. There were fragile internal hemorrhoids, but no obvious spots or clear source of bleeding.

**HOSPITAL COURSE**  
The patient was taken to the emergency room by Dr. X. An NG tube was placed and the stomach fluid did not show blood. Dr. Y Miller saw him and suggested a colonoscopy. A bowel prep was done. His hemoglobin and hematocrit (H&H) were stable. The most recent H&H was 38.6/13.2 this morning; at admission it was 41/14.3. The bowel prep did not show significant bleeding. Vital signs stayed stable.  

He continues his usual medicines: Imdur (nitroglycerin), metoprolol (a beta‑blocker), and Synthroid (thyroid hormone). Plavix (a blood thinner) was stopped. He received IV Protonix (a stomach acid reducer). The doctor was cautious about using Prilosec or Protonix because of his history of pancreatitis linked to Prilosec.  

Blood clotting tests were normal: PT/INR 1.03, PTT 25.8. Chemistry panel was normal. After the colonoscopy he was given a regular diet, which he tolerated well. He is being sent home.  

**FOLLOW‑UP**  
He will be closely monitored as an outpatient. He will keep taking Pepcid 40 mg at night, Imdur, Synthroid, and metoprolol as before. Plavix will be held for now. If he has more dark stools, he should call the office and avoid Pepto‑Bismol. He will have a follow‑up appointment on Thursday.
